name: Jlm resume
body:
http://gurucareers.com/13-highly-slick-and-professional-cv-templates/


WRITTEN BY Andy Selway

Lots of advice that is categorised as “Job Interview Tips” should really filed under “Tips For Not Being Rude, Foolish, and Generally Clueless.” Read these 7 interview tips that WILL help you.

If you’ve made it to the point of interviewing for a job, chances are, you know to arrive ten minutes early and to dress appropriately for the company culture. If you still need to be reminded of this, you might be beyond our help. But if you already know the basics of not messing up big at your interview and want a few more tips on how to avoid big pitfalls, read on!


Far too many candidates go into interviews knowing the company with which they’re interviewing back and forth, up and down but not having a clue about the person in front of them asking the questions. With social networks like LinkedIn and Twitter and company websites with easy-to-find staff bios, it is easier than ever to figure out who you’ll be talking to and prepare to speak to their particular interests and role in the company.


You may have your elevator pitch down and know how to talk about your weaknesses (or development areas!) in a way that doesn’t sabotage your chances, but do you have fresh ideas for what you’ll do with the role? You don’t need to come into the interview ready to remake the department but having some vision for what you’ll do in the job is critical to standing apart from the competition.


It is a hiring manager’s job to ask about gaps in your work history or if you’re changing industries. They aren’t looking to catch you doing something wrong, they just want to know what you’ve been up to that has brought you to now. Being defensive about your decisions or being excessively verbose in your explanations will make you look unsure of yourself, that you are telling a fib and seem like you have less certainty and direction. You don’t want to leave your interview with the hiring manager feeling perplexed and confused.


Hiring managers love to know that you want to stay at a company long enough to be promoted, but if you ask too many questions about mobility within the firm or how long people usually stay in the job you’re interviewing for, it signals that you’re not entirely focused on the current job. It’s great to be keen on progression, but this needs to be in moderation and you need to be realistic on the timescales.


Lots of candidates ask about the company culture and the typical day, but forget that they are being interviewed for a set of very specific tasks. Directly referring to the set of tasks that appeared in the original job description signals to the hiring manager that you’re thinking about the job at hand and how well you can do it for them, which is going to be key to deciding whether or not you’re the best fit.


Everyone knows to come prepared with questions for their interviewer. Not everyone knows that, “What do you like about working here?” is a bit of a tired one. You can certainly ask it as a matter of being friendly and personable but if you fail to ask original and engaging questions about the job, you miss an opportunity for your critical thinking about the position to stand out. Have questions prepared that refer to both your interview so they have a chance to talk about their work and about how they envision your potential role working within the company. Then you can ask about the culture.


A follow up email is always appropriate, even if the hiring manager says that they’ll be in touch with more information. You should proactively reach out to thank them for their time and include both a reiteration of your enthusiasm about the job based on something you discussed in the interview and a question for them. By asking a question, you keep them engaged with your candidacy and let them know that you were thinking more about the job even after you walked out the door, making them more likely to invite you back in. This is a great way to stand out from other candidates who may not have done this! But don’t turn into a stalker!

Andy Selway is the Founder of ‘Your HR Consultancy’ which provides HR & people solutions to start-ups and SMEs. Andy also runs Corporate and Cocktails, which is fast becoming one of London’s biggest growing HR communities with over 1,700 HR members.


We’re a successful marketing agency with a varied, interesting portfolio of third party clients and first party sites. Our sites range from large content-and community platforms through ecommerce offerings to B2B and B2C brochure-style sites. Clients range from local to national to international and from ice cream producers to multinational consultancies.


Competitive – South West England, BA1 2PW

Due to our busy workload and expansion plans, we’re looking for a front-end developer to join us for 2-3 months. Working in our office in Bath, the bulk of the work will be front-end development of new websites and amends and improvements to existing sites. There will also be some back-end work and email template creation. 

If you have any experience building templates for Django-based websites, that’d be great; otherwise, we’ll help you train up on the job. 

We’re a successful marketing agency with a varied, interesting portfolio of third party clients and first party sites. Our sites range from large content-and-community platforms through ecommerce offerings to B2B and B2C brochure-style sites. Clients range from local to national to international and from ice cream producers to multinational consultancies. 


Required skills
– Ability to hand code (X) HTML5 and CSS3 from Photoshop designs
– Good knowledge of Javascript, especially jQuery
– Experience of building responsive websites
– Ability to work autonomously and in a team
– Happy to take a turn in the tea round


Nice to have skills
– Familiarity with CoffeeScript, Node.js, Yeoman, Bootstrap, CSS framewords, such as LESS or Sass
– Experience with Python, preferably with Django
– Experience with PostgreSQL databases
– Experience with PHP/MySQL, especially Magento and CakePHP
– Good knowledge of source control


How to apply
Please apply with your CV and the following:
– A portfolio of commercial work that you’ve completed
– Any examples of personal projects you’ve completed in your spare time
– Any relevant links to Github/Bitbucket etc projects you’ve contributed to in any way

Summary
I am a junior developer familiar with the fundamentals of MVC and BDD, and constantly pursuing my passion to continuously learn new languages, frameworks and techniques in order to become a better computer programmer. I have always been drawn to tech in all its forms, and over the last year, I've dabbled in many different programming languages and web development platforms. What really excites me about programming is the near-constant sense of working on an elaborate puzzle, and the great satisfaction that comes when all the pieces fit together and the final picture appears.

Check out my code projects by clicking the link below to my GitHub account.
(The picture was automatically added by LinkedIn by scraping my GitHub profile pic... I'm not actually that vain.)

Responsibilities:

The Web Developer will work on both new site projects and operational support requests. This is a hands-on coding role
that requires strong individual contribution and rapid learning of new technologies as you work. You will create custom
Drupal modules and templates using PHP, write JavaScript and jQuery code from scratch, apply look & feel styling using
Compass/SASS, and build code to integrate with internalsystems. You will collaborate daily with project
managers, QA testers, and business owners for project requirements, testing phases, and code deployments. Problem
triage and quick resolution will be needed for any reported site issues.
Create a new PHP site template and write CSS from scratch to show a schedule of games.
Create responsive pages that include editorial content, ads, and pre-built site components.
Create a new editorial form in Drupal for publishing stories, photos, or video.
Retrieve and display live game scores and statistics using AJAX.
Auto import images into Drupal from Getty Images or other image source API.
Write code to integrate with a HTML5/Flash video player, Google DFP ads, and site analytics.
Fix a styling issue specifically for iOS or Android smartphones and tablets.
Key Skills:

2+ years of enterprise-level web experience (high traffic sites, complex UI features)
PHP, JavaScript, jQuery, CSS, JSON/XML are required.
Experience with responsive designs and basic Unix commands is preferred.
Writing custom modules or plugins for Drupal and Wordpress as a back-end CMS is a plus.
Bootstrap, Compass, SASS are a plus.
Git for version control is a plus.

Buod
I enjoy learning new skills, solving complicated problems, and implementing solutions that "just work".

Mga Kakayahan:node.js, JavaScript, Drupal, mysql, php, memcached, apache, c++, java, python

Created a public facing information update collection and verification application which provided new integration with existing CRM and prospect management systems securely.
+ Developed in Zend Framework (MVC) with Doctrine ORM tying to a MySQL backend.

+ Multi-layer security approaches to prevent spam, abuse, and fraud even with an initial anonymous entry.

Buod
I'm an adaptive programmer who enjoys new challenges and seeks continuous improvement. I'm adept at learning new skills and toolsets in web development. I'm collaborative, team-oriented, and experienced in facilitating communication. My projects emphasize performant architecture and a willingness to revise.

I am a software engineer based in Austin TX, currently working for Four Kitchens building large-scale, enterprise-level web sites and web applications.

I have experience working with JavaScript (Node.js), PHP, C, Objective-C, Drupal, Meteor, Express, WordPress, Symphony, and CodeIgniter.

In my spare time you can find me working on open source projects, most of which are on my Github account: https://github.com/patrickocoffeyo. I also take time to write on my personal blog: http://patrickcoffey.io

- You know your way around image and vector editing software (Fireworks, Illustrator, Photoshop, Gimp, etc.)
- GIT insight
- Familiar with CMSs, e.g. Drupal
- You're prompt and enjoy learning new things
- English language proficiency in both speaking and writing
Additional prefered Qualifications

- Backbone.js
- Node.js
Required work Experience
- At least two years
